Title: Samantha Akkineni just turned designer and we can't wait to wear her clothes!
Content: Telugu cinema's most loved female superstar, Samantha Akkineni has stirred up the Indian fashion world by announcing her own fashion label. Yes, you read that right.One of the most fashionable celebrities down south, Samantha is set to launch her own clothing brand called 'Saaki' which has been tagged as a fashion exploration by Samantha for the collective modern woman.The label claims that every design of their's has a story and every story has a journey.In her Instagram post about the label, Samantha wrote, "Saaki is a reflection of who I am, as I am."She added, "Saaki has been a dream of mine, and my baby for many months. ...It is a reflection of my love for fashion and my journey in life."Samantha also confessed that in college, there was no way that she could afford a designer outfit. But since she started acting, she's had the honour of wearing clothes designed by talented designers and launching her own label is an emotional moment for her.Well, with her personal style being so chic we can't wait to try her clothes already. Tell us what do you think about Samantha's foray into the world of fashion.

Title: #KolkataBraveheart: Was a victim of domestic violence, had to protest
Content:
Beacon of hope, mentally strong, courageous

‚Äî

Anuj Sharma

, CP, Kolkata Police

‚Äî Dr

Kunal Sengupta

, who is treating Nilanjana

‚Äî

Deep Satpathi

Two days after her surgery, we meet Nilanjana Chatterjee at a city hospital, where she is recuperating with the help of her doctors, physiotherapist and nurses and hoping to be back on her feet soon. ‚ÄúI must get well soon and start walking. I have to look after my elderly parents,‚Äù the braveheart tells us from the hospital bed, setting another example of her undying spirit. In a candid chat with CT, Nilanjana ‚Äì who is making headlines for her awe-inspiring act of bravery on Saturday night when she came to the rescue of a 31-year-old woman who was molested and thrown out of a car that also left the saviour with a fractured shin bone ‚Äì reveals the darkest secrets of her personal life and the reason why she never thinks twice before standing up for what‚Äôs right. Excerpts:I don‚Äôt see this as an act of bravery. I just did what any normal human being should do. I can only hope that this entire incident encourages more people to come forward and help others in need. My parents are very happy. My father, who suffers from Parkinson‚Äôs, told me, ‚ÄòHats off to you, my child‚Äô. They deserve all the credit for my bravery. ‚ÄòHave a strong backbone and live with your head held high‚Äô ‚Äì this is what they have always taught me.Before Deep (Satpathi, husband), I was married to an Air Force doctor in 1996. That was an arranged marriage. In 1997, my daughter was born. I was subjected to domestic violence by my then husband. I was physically and mentally abused. My mom used to tell me, ‚ÄòIf you do not come out of this marriage, you‚Äôll have to stop calling me Ma‚Äô. That was the kind of support I got from my parents. After a long battle ‚Äì for divorce and my daughter‚Äôs custody ‚Äì I finally won freedom. I was tortured because my husband was in a relationship with someone else but could not go against his family to marry her. They got married after our divorce. When I married Deep, he held my hands and told me, ‚ÄòLet‚Äôs bring up Titli (daughter) together the way we want to‚Äô.For me, my ex-husband didn‚Äôt qualify as a human being, and I have the same views about Abhishek Kumar Pandey , who attacked me and abused that woman. I am happy that he has been arrested. I hope the law takes its course and he gets punished. I‚Äôd never want to meet him. I‚Äôll protest every time I come across violence against women, and that is what I have taught my daughter too.The girl I tried to help on Saturday night called Deep to enquire about my health condition. I am told that she is too scared to speak the whole truth. I don‚Äôt blame her. I have a daughter and understand the trauma of this girl. But I did not save her just because I am a mother. I did it because it was the right thing to do. In such cases, the patriarchal society that we live in is quick to question the integrity of the women involved. Why was she out so late? Who was the man she went out with? What was she wearing? These are just some of the common questions on everyone‚Äôs mind, which become the talking point.After this incident, a lot of my friends and family members expressed disapproval for what we did. ‚ÄòWhy did you get into this trouble?‚Äô they asked. We told them that we‚Äôd do it again if we have to. For this is a question of right and wrong. I have received enough support from Kolkata Police, our government and media friends. This support means that in this city if you come forward to help, you are not going to be a lone fighter. The cops and administration will support you. May my kollolini Kolkata become a better and safer place.I‚Äôve told Nilanjana Chatterjee that she is a beacon of hope for women, as her act will inspire them to speak out against atrocities. We are always with them. She is the #TrueTejashwini and I salute her. I would request the citizens to dial 100 in time of crisis. We will respond swiftly to their needs as we did in this case.Nilanjana‚Äôs threshold for pain is unimaginable. Even an army man would lie low if he gets wounded by a bullet on his leg. But Nilanjana smiled all through. This comes from enormous mental strength. We had a plastic surgeon during the surgery so that we could minimise the scar. Usually, women are touchy about scars. But Nilanjana doesn‚Äôt seem to care much. She is brave! From today, we will give her walker support and see if she can walk.I first saw Nilanjana in a video clip from an office party. She was performing a Rabindrasangeet. I immediately told my friends that I must meet her. We continue to be friends. When I proposed to marry her, she initially refused and we were out of touch for a year. Later, she agreed. I respect her courage and we are bringing up our daughter as a socially responsible,fearless woman. I know we are not alone in this journey. On the day of her surgery, which was a lockdown day, a septuagenarian man (Rabin Patra) cycled all the way from Beleghata to the hospital just to express solidarity with us after reading our story in the newspapers. He gave me a hand-written congratulatory note. He also alerted his son that he would need to come down if there‚Äôs any requirement for blood during Nilanjana‚Äôs surgery. That is the magic of Kolkata. I hope Nilanjana‚Äôs act and the cops‚Äô cooperation keep this spirit alive.

Title: Prabhu Mundkur dons an intense look in Pradeep Varma‚Äôs next film
Content: After having played the boy-next-door in his outings so far, actor Prabhu Mundkur has now made a detour to play a rather experimental character in his next movie. The actor, who has undergone a major makeover for the same, is the latest addition to the team of director Pradeep Varma ‚Äôs upcoming project,. ‚ÄúThe movie is a futuristic one, and is set 5,000 years hence. So, when Pradeep narrated the concept to me, I was left intrigued. The film opens with my story and I play the head of a clan that is one of the last few to be surviving on earth. Time has regressed and with all technology having been wiped out, we struggle to live and carry forth our generation,‚Äù says Prabhu, giving a little insight into the narrative.Talking about his look in the film, he says, ‚ÄúThe shabby look that I portray is owing to the many adversities that I face to protect my family, and it has a telling effect on me.‚Äù The actor‚Äôs turnout was conceptualised by Pradeep himself, while his sister Lavanya worked on the makeup and styling was handled by Sindhu and Divya Reddy.‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not often that one gets such parts in one‚Äôs career, so I was stoked when it came my way,‚Äù adds the actor, who is all set to work with Pradeep in January in another flick, titledMeanwhile,, which is set in a fictitious land, also features Anupama Gowda, Sathya BG, Mayuri Nataraja, Bhavani Prakash and Raghava in prominent roles. Its cinematography is done by Anand Suresha, music by Luka Lauri from Georgia and editing by Srikanth.

Title: CM Yediyurappa to help Sandalwood find its footing again: Shivarajkumar
Content: The Kannada film industry has been out of action for close to six months, since the pandemic broke out. It is only in recent times that some film teams have ventured out to test shooting in the new normal. But those are only baby steps for the industry, which has been severely impacted by the lockdown. Theatres are yet to reopen, there‚Äôs no word on when that could happen and, if audiences will warm up to the idea of cinema outings after such a long time.Back in July, senior members of Sandalwood had met at Shivarajkumar‚Äôs residence to discuss the issues they faced and what it would take to get the industry up and running again. The actor was then entrusted with the responsibility of representing them in future deliberations with government officials, the first of which took place on Wednesday. Shivarajkumar led a delegation of industry members in back-to-back meetings with chief minister BS Yediyurappa and deputy chief minister Dr Ashwath Narayan.Shivarajkumar says, "We went to the meeting with members including producers, directors, exhibitors, etc. Yash, Duniya Vijay and I represented the actors. During the meeting, we presented the issues faced by the industry in detail, including those related to tax, GST, etc., and what we think could be done at a government level to help us tide over this distressing situation. The chief minister has assured us that he would discuss our relief requests with heads of relevant departments and revert with what can be done. Overall, it was a good meeting and we are hopeful of positive results."The actor adds that the proposed film city at Hesaraghatta also came up for discussion. "We had met Dr Ashwath Narayan before our appointment with the CM. He assured that the government would do its best to help the industry. He also said that he was directly involved with the work on the film city and said that there would be progress in this regard soon enough," he says.

Title: Eating out in the new normal: Avoid crossed tables, scan QR codes for menu, sanitised cutlery in wraps
Content: The pandemic and the subsequent new normal that we have come to accept as part of it entail changes in how we lead our lives that many of us never imagined. Today, pretty much everything requires us to be tech savvy, with digital communication and transactions, among others, the norm. Something as simple as heading to your favourite darshini for piping hot masala dose and coffee, or a more dignified dine-out experience at a popular restaurant, is a little more complicated today, with pretty much every step from ordering to payment going online. But these changes, say stakeholders, will go a long way in reassuring patrons that their safety is top priority while adapting to the new normal. BT did a spot check at some of the city hot spots to give you a clear picture of what eating out looks like now‚Ä¶Service with precautionsApart from routine temperature checks for staff and guests, restaurants insist on face shields and gloves for staff, which are changed regularly. Beside sanitiser dispensers at the entrance, many venues provide it at the table as well. While restaurants are open to the idea of patrons carrying their own cutlery, they do provide sanitised cutlery in bags that will only be opened by customers.Your attention pleaseSome of the cafes and bistros in the city have boards outside their premises with all the precautionarymeasures and procedures for people, to reiterate their new ways of service during this pandemic.Distanced bar stools and tablesSince the reopening of bars and pubs in the city, some venues have done away with service at the barcompletely, while others have decided to space out bar stools in keeping with social distancing norms. Some restaurants have marked tables that cannot be occupied to ensure adequate distance between guests.QR codes are the normFrom having to declare your health status outside some restaurants to surfing the menus for dine-in or takeaways to even paying your bills, QR codes have made their way to the F&B industry. Interestingly enough, it is not just pubs and fine-dining restaurants, but even some iconic traditional restaurants that have made the switch to facilitate seamless service and cut down crowds.(Based on inputs from Arun Adiga of Vidyarthi Bhavan, Aman Dua of Raahi and Akanksha Chaudhary from JSM Corporation)

Title: Destination weddings trend in heart of Incredible India
Content: INDORE: The coronavirus pandemic has squeezed the big fat Indian weddings into a small intimate affair though the love for destination marriages much affordable with an exclusive small guest list at exquisite sites has risen. MPTDC ) has booked around 100 destination weddings so far for winter months at different locations across the state including Orcha, Khajuraho , Gandhi Sagar, Maheshwar, Mandu and Hanuwantiya.Of these 15 weddings have been booked for various tourist destinations in Indore division. The excuse to chop off guests amid the outbreak of pandemic and the luxury to afford a destination wedding almost at the cost equivalent to a posh hotel is the key in driving the trend for destination marriages, said officials and wedding experts.MTDC MD S Vishwanathan said, ‚ÄúWe have received around 100 bookings for destination weddings so far for different properties and enquiries are regularly pouring in. As the guests list has shortened and other expenses have come down, destination weddings are clicking in and it also adds to the experience of people. We are glad to see the confidence of people in our properties where we follow all laid safety protocols by the WHO and the health department.‚ÄùMost of the enquiries for destination weddings in the state are coming for properties close to lake, water bodies, heritage properties and resorts situated in the lap of nature. Anubhav Verma, an IT professional working at Pune has booked a hotel in Maheswar for his younger brother‚Äôs wedding. Verma said, ‚ÄúDestination wedding was never on the cards but after the outbreak of pandemic we decided to keep the function a low key in the presence of dear ones and started exploring options. This place suited us and there was not much impact on the budget as well so we decided to go for it.‚ÄùAccording to wedding experts, many middle class families are also making enquiries for hosting destination weddings. Some of the top preferred destinations out of state are Jaipur, Jaisalmer, Udaipur and Goa.Bhavna Jadon, a wedding planner said, ‚ÄúInstead of inviting 500-1,000 guests, host families are calling limited 100-150 guests and spending the money on their leisure. They are booking special charters and more exquisite destinations. Expenses are the same but due to less number of guests, they are adding more leisure to their wedding plans.‚Äù According to MPTDC, Indore region they had booked 5 destination weddings last year as against 15 so far for December and January months. Ajay Sharma, regional manager, MPTDC, Indore region said, ‚ÄúNew places are being booked for weddings this year such as Sailani, Hanuwantiya and Gandhi Sagar. Until last year, we had booked resorts at Ujjain and Maheshwar for organizing weddings. With fewer guests people have to spend less on catering and rooms and this is making destination weddings more attractive.‚Äù

Title: Delhi Metro's Red, Violet, Green lines to resume services on Thursday
Content:
Representational Image

NEW DELHI: Services on the Delhi Metro 's Red, Violet and Green lines are set to resume on Thursday, officials said, after remaining suspended for over five months due to the Covid-19 pandemic.

The Delhi Metro opened its doors to commuters on Monday with curtailed operation of the Yellow Line. Metro services in Delhi-NCR were closed since March 22.

The Ministry of Home Affairs had recently issued guidelines allowing the Delhi Metro to resume operations in a graded manner, following which the DMRC had said it would be done in three stages from September 7-12.

As part of stage one, the Yellow Line or Line 2 and Rapid Metro were made operational with restricted service hours. Trains are operating in two batches -- from 7-11 AM and 4-8 PM -- in the first stage.

On Wednesday, the Blue and Pink lines were made operational with the same schedule.

The Red Line (Rithala to Shaheed Sthal New Bus Adda (Ghaziabad); Green Line (Kirti Nagar/Inderlok to Brig. Hosihar Singh); and Violet Line (Kashmere Gate to Raja Nahar Singh) will resume services from September 10 with the same time schedule, the Delhi Metro Rail Corporation (DMRC) said on Wednesday.

With services available on multiple lines (Yellow, Blue and Pink Lines), the total ridership on Wednesday was nearly 53,400 till 8 PM, the DMRC said in a statement.

The Yellow Line saw an approximate ridership of 26,900, the Blue Line 22,600 and the Pink Line 3,900, it said.

The DMRC said it "will be running 35 trains on the Red Line performing around 413 train trips during morning and evening hours on 10th September, 2020".

"Similarly, 40 trains with approximately 344 trips will be put into service on the Violet Line," it said.

On the Green Line, 20 trains with 268 trips will be put into service, it added.

"The trips will be subsequently increased as the operational timing of services get extended on September 11-12 with the opening of other lines in a graded manner," the DMRC said.

The list of gates which will remain open for entry of passengers at each station along with all necessary updates are available on the home page of the Delhi Metro's official website, www.delhimetrorail.com.

The entire metro network will be made operational throughout the day from September 12 onwards. Passengers will be required to follow all social distancing norms and guidelines during travel.

Wearing masks is mandatory inside train coaches and on station premises.

The DMRC has appealed to people to use the rapid transport only if urgently needed.

Title: India China border news: India, China hope to pull back from brink in likely meeting
Content:
File photo

NEW DELHI: India and China will look to pull back from the brink of a military conflict in a likely meeting between foreign minister S Jaishankar and his Chinese counterpart Wang Yi on the margins of SCO in Moscow Thursday. While the Chinese foreign ministry didn't confirm the meeting in its press briefing, despite being repeatedly asked about it, Chinese sources here said it was expected, even if there was "no confirmed information".

There was not much to inspire confidence though about the overall situation with Chinese sources Wednesday repeating PLA claims that Indian soldiers "provoked" the Chinese by crossing LAC in the southern bank area of Pangong Tso and opening fire. Indian officials here didn't hazard any guess about the outcome of the meeting on Thursday.

Jaishankar will also join Wang and Russian foreign minister Sergey Lavrov for a luncheon meeting before the proposed bilateral with Wang.

The trilateral meeting was first announced by the Chinese foreign ministry and later confirmed by Indian and Russian diplomatic sources. While Russia had said this week that it will encourage any effort for dialogue between India and China, official sources said there was no question of Moscow mediating in the eastern Ladakh border standoff.

"RIC (Russia-India-China) foreign ministers even in the past have had separate meetings on the margins of multilateral fora like BRICS and SCO," said a government source. While bilateral disputes can't be raised at SCO, diplomatic sources said one of the aims of the Eurasian group is to promote "good neighborly ties" between the member-states and the platform can always be used to build mutual trust between them. As the host nation, Russia had the main role in organising the meeting.

The trilateral could help break the ice ahead of what will be the first in-person bilateral meeting between Jaishankar and Wang after the ongoing military standoff was reported in May. Jaishankar is likely to insist on China restoring the pre-April status quo at LAC and on early and complete disengagement by implementing the understandings arrived at in the meetings of the senior commanders since June 6. The government has been trying to drive home the point that the behaviour of the Chinese troops, which led to another flare-up in the southern bank area of Pangong Tso this week, will seriously damage bilateral ties.

Before thinking in terms of a breakthrough though, the 2 leaders will have to first address the situation that led to, as the Indian army said, shots being fired at LAC on Monday for the first time in 45 years. India has strongly denied claims that Indian soldiers crossed the LAC.

The situation at Pangong seemed to have changed recently with Indian soldiers taking control of strategic peaks on the southern bank. The PLA has protested bitterly what government sources have described as "readjustment" in deployment of Indian troops in the area and Wang is likely to raise the same in the meeting.



In Video: LAC row: India, China hope to avoid military conflict, foreign ministers likely to meet at SCO today

Title: Madhuri Dixit Nene is in a musical mood
Content: There‚Äôs no doubt that Madhuri Dixit Nene is musically inclined. Not only is she a fantastic dancer, but she even has a melodious voice. She recently sang and shot a video for her single, Candle. And it looks like she is a musical mood these days. Along with a stunning picture, the actress shared lyrics of the song 'Chupke Se Sun Iss Pal Ki Dhun' from the film ' Mission Kashmir '. Check out the post here:In a recent interview, Madhuri spoke about why she decided to lend her vocals to the song, which was shot at home by her husband Dr Sriram Nene. She said, ‚ÄúI decided to sing for the video because people have never seen me do that. I am happy that it turned out well. I used to sing even on the TV shows that I have judged, but that was mostly in Hindi. In Bollywood , people are used to hearing playback singers sing for us. I sang a bit in ' Devdas ' ('Dhaai Sham Rok Lai') and ' Gulaab Gang '. My education has been in English, as I attended a convent school.In school, too, I sang only in English, so I was used to it. No one knew about my musical talent because I never spoke about it on any public platform."

Title: Exclusive: Tara Sutaria is honing her singing skills; hoping to do a live gig soon!
Content: Tara Sutaria‚Äôs love for singing is well known. It isn‚Äôt a surprise then that the actress used the time that she spent at home, over the past few months, to hone her singing skills. Tara, who is a trained singer, says, ‚ÄúThis break allowed me to research different singers from around the world. I have been watching them perform and observing their technique to figure out how to use them in the studio and at concerts. I have also been watching many documentaries, series and videos of my favourite artistes from India and abroad. The past few months have given me a lot of time to focus on music.‚ÄùDuring an interaction with Bombay Times in 2019, Tara had said that her New Year resolution would be to look for opportunities related to music. She had said, ‚ÄúWhile this year (2019), I focused on acting, next year, I will also look for musical opportunities. I want singing to be a huge part of my next year.‚Äù It looks like the actress has been able to keep her resolution. Tara adds, ‚ÄúI‚Äôve performed at music concerts all my life, in India as well as abroad, and it‚Äôs something I can‚Äôt wait to get back to. I‚Äôve been training classically and in musical theatre since I was five. In fact, my last concert was at the Royal Opera House in Mumbai, just before I made my debut with Student of the Year 2 .‚ÄùInterestingly, in her forthcoming film Ek Villain 2, Tara reportedly plays a singer. At an event before the lockdown, she had even hinted at singing for the film. While the actress doesn‚Äôt want to reveal much about the Mohit Suri directorial, she opens up about the Hindi remake of the Telugu film, RX 100, in which she will be seen opposite Suniel Shetty‚Äôs son, Ahan. ‚ÄúBefore the lockdown, we were shooting for the film. We have finished most of it, just the last bit of the film is left, which we will complete once it is safe to do so,‚Äù she says.Meanwhile, at home, she is also spending a lot of time with her twin sister, Pia. ‚ÄúThis phase gave us a lot of time to hang out with each other at home. Before that, we were busy with our crazy schedules. Now at home, we have been watching movies and listening to music that we have grown up hearing and reconnecting in so many ways. We also got time to have conversations about the work that we are doing, the work that we admire, the performances that we like from across the globe. We got nostalgic looking at family photo albums and watching old videos,‚Äù she signs off.

Title: World Suicide Prevention Day: Time to address mental health issues leading to suicide, say experts
Content: We are in the midst of a pandemic, but we are also in the middle of another crisis. The past few months have seen an alarming rise in cases of suicide across the city. What has also come to the fore is that the state of Maharashtra is reported to have had the highest suicide rate. On World Suicide Prevention Day (WSPD) today, mental health experts tell us what‚Äôs pushing people over the edge.There are a variety of causes that are pushing people towards the edge, states clinical psychologist and psychotherapist, Dr Varkha Chulani. She explains, ‚ÄúMaharashtra has the highest suicide rate, which includes farmers‚Äô suicides. There has also been so much economic distress. Mumbai, for instance, is an expensive city to live in and to afford things as simple as hospital care. Then there are social pressures to constantly being compelled to keep up with the Joneses. So, the pressure to conform to certain expenses, looks, and even competitiveness, where seats are few compared to people applying for positions in colleges or companies ‚Äî all make for variables in tipping the person over.‚ÄùThe new normal due to the pandemic paints an extremely grim picture ‚Äî distress and misery in emergency rooms, social isolation, rising cases and fears, all of these are red flags with potential long-term consequences. ‚ÄúI have said this on several forums. The current situation with regard to mental health is like a ticking bomb waiting to burst,‚Äù says psychiatrist Harish Shetty, adding, ‚ÄúWhy do people contemplate taking their lives in this environment? It‚Äôs a mix of things ‚Äî fear of death, fear of illness and fear of uncertainty. For many who have died, the families have not seen their faces as they were cremated by the state, so there was no closure at all. The lack of stimulative social interactions adds to this. Today, we are looking at a massive mental health avalanche, but we continue to be blind to it.I shared key points with the state government‚Äôs COVID-19 task force. While we are only focusing on deaths related to coronavirus , what we need to realise is that with mental issues, you end up dying every single day. It could be a breeding ground for suicide.‚ÄùFor solutions, Dr Chulani says, ‚ÄúWhen we raise unachievable benchmarks, we are going to be devastated. The reconstruction of perfection and that third best is also good enough, should be the goal. The core, for me as a professional, is that there is no training ‚Äî self-taught or via parents and schools ‚Äî that ascertains how to cope. When something bad happens, people give it a positive spin, saying, ‚ÄòEverything happens for the best.‚Äô No, it doesn‚Äôt. But one has to face it, it‚Äôs not the end of the world.‚ÄùDr Shetty adds, ‚ÄúUnless we focus on mental health completely and take macro decisions, there will be cases of anxiety, phobia, depression and suicide. For instance, every coronavirus task force should have a mental health professional.‚ÄùWorld Suicide Prevention Day is observed globally today, in order to reiterate worldwide commitment to prevent suicides. It aims to generate awareness that suicide can be prevented through various activities and awareness programmes.Maharashtra is said to be the suicide capital of India with one in seven cases. The number of suicides rose 4.7% in Mumbai, placing it fourth among Indian cities. According to a recent report, suicides in India ‚Äî often called the world‚Äôs suicide capital ‚Äî increased 3.4% from 1.34 lakh in 2018 to 1.39 lakh.

Title: Siddharth Chandekar and Mitali Mayekar postpone their wedding to 2021

Title: Television actress Sravani Kondapalli dies by suicide, family book a case against ex-boyfriend Devaraj Reddy
Content: In an incident that has sent shock waves across the Telugu television industry, Sravani Kondapalli of Manasu Mamata and Mounaragam fame, died by suicide on Tuesday night. The 26-year-old TV actor was found hanging at her Madhuranagar residence in Hyderabad, by her brother Shiva, who alerted the police. He also filed a complaint at the SR Nagar PS alleging that she resorted to the extreme step due to constant harassment by her ex-boyfriend Devaraj Reddy . According to Shiva, Devaraj got acquainted with Sravani after approaching her on TikTok , saying that he was interested in acting in television shows.Recounting the events that transpired on the night Sravani took her life, Shiva said: ‚ÄúShe told us she had a shoot on Wednesday morning and went into her room saying she had to wash her hair. She locked her room. My mother was making dinner for us and waiting for her to come out. When Sravani did not come out of her room for a long time, we knocked on her door but she didn‚Äôt respond. We got worried and that‚Äôs when I tried to look inside, through the window. I could sense something was wrong. I called my akka‚Äôs friend immediately and he came over. Together we broke the door open, but it was too late. We rushed her to a private hospital nearby, but she was declared brought dead.‚Äù Sravani‚Äôs mortal remains were shifted to Osmania General Hospital for post-mortem.Alleging that it was Devaraj who pushed her to take her life, Shiva added, ‚ÄúHe had been blackmailing my sister using some personal pictures. She even paid him ‚Çπ30,000 and ‚Çπ80,000 on two separate occasions. But he continued to harass her. On Tuesday night, she had told us that he was blackmailing her again. she was feeling terrible about it. But we never thought she would take this step.‚ÄùCircle Inspector V Narasimha Reddy of SR Nagar Police Station, where a case against Devaraj has been registered under Section 306 of the IPC, meanwhile, has a different narrative: ‚ÄúSravani‚Äôs parents had brought her to the police station on June 22. She had known him for a year. They made her file a complaint against Devaraj, in which she stated that he was harassing her. He was arrested and reprimanded by the court at that time. However, they met again recently. her family found out about it and were not happy about it. There was a discussion about this on Tuesday night. She hanged herself between 8-9 pm, following that conversation,‚Äù he said, adding, ‚ÄúHer family has now alleged that she killed herself due to harassment by Devaraj, so he has been booked for abetment to suicide. We have sent a team to Kakinada to bring him to the city. He will be arrested if proven guilty.‚ÄùHer parents are lying! A man called Sai is the reason she killed herself. I was the last person she spoke to, she told me her family was torturing her and she wanted to elope with me. She also told me her family and Sai humiliated her and beat her up. The blackmailing case they‚Äôve slapped on me is false; they have absolutely no proof. The case they filed against me in June was false as well; they coerced her into filing it. Recently, she asked me to marry her and I refused because I was hurt that she had filed a case against me. A few days ago, I met her at a restaurant. Sai came there and he tried to kill himself, and then he beat her up right in front of me. She went home and fought with her parents about it. I have proofs of the same because she was on call with me when she fought with them. I will submit it all to the police. Yes, she did transfer ‚Çπ30,000 thousand to me once, but it was for a party she was hosting. I have never taken money from her. She loved me whole-heartedly and that‚Äôs the only issue her parents had with me.

Title: Anil Kapoor loves watching the sunset by the sea
Content: There‚Äôs no doubt that Anil Kapoor is among the fittest men in Bollywood . The actor never goes easy or skips his fitness regime. It looks like Anil, who was last seen in the film ‚Äò Malang ‚Äô, loves working out in open spaces. These days, he has been posting pictures and videos of him spending time at the beach, which is close to his house. And it seems that he loves gazing at the sunset. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs something magical about watching the sunset by the sea... #sunsetdiaries #goldenhour,‚Äù he wrote with a picture that he shared recently on his social media handle. Check out the post here:While Anil and wife Sunita are in Mumbai these days, daughter Sonam K Ahuja is spending time in London with husband Anand Ahuja . But she does keep in touch with her dad not just over the phone, but also comments on his social media post. Recently when he uploaded a video of him walking on the beach, Jackie Shroff wrote, ‚ÄúAwesome Lakhan.‚Äù He was referring to their film, ‚ÄòRam Lakhan‚Äô. Sonam reacted to his comment, saying, ‚ÄúDo a movie together.‚Äù Their fans definitely would want them to see them sharing screen space again.
