Title: MHT CET from October 1, MBA admission from 2nd week of month
Content: Mumbai: MHT-CET for admissions to engineering and pharmacy courses in the state will now be held between October 1 and 20. Around 5.3 lakh students have registered for the test.In the PCB (physics, chemistry, and biology) group, 2.8 lakh students have registered this year and the exams are scheduled on October 1, 2, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, and 9. For the PCM (physics, chemistry, and mathematics) group, 2.5 lakh students have registered. The exam for the PCM group is scheduled on October 12, 13, 14, 15, 16, 19, and 20.The detailed schedule and link for downloading admit cards will be made available on the official website www.mahacet.org. Candidates can visit the site for regular updates and notices too. An official said since JEE (main) was conducted across the state with good attendance, it will be easier to hold CET spread across 20 days.Meanwhile, the centralized admission process (CAP) rounds for MBA/MMS admissions in the state will commence from the second week of October, after the results of final-year degree exams are out, said higher and technical education minister Uday Samant on Wednesday.

Title: The Towns Mirror Special: Meet the Fosters
Content:
Ashwin Pethi

Brijesh Nambiar

dog

Most people took in puppies during the lockdown. Now that offices have started functioning, many pets have been abandoned ‚Äî Cooke Town resident

many pets

Labrador

Athreya Chidambi

Townies

By Sudeshna DuttaIt‚Äôs an emotionally draining experience, said no pet foster parent ever. Let‚Äôs hear it for these people with hearts of goldWhencome across Layla who was hit and run by a car, he took her in and nursed her back to health. But soon it was time to give her up for adoption. ‚ÄúShe went in and out of multiple homes. People used to return her to me since they could not handle her energetic behaviour. I have four dogs and keeping Layla was not an option for me.‚ÄùBeing a foster parent is never easy, but many large hearted people in East Bengaluru do it, knowing that they are setting themselves up for heart break. But they will always choose heart break than see an animal suffer alone on the streets.says, ‚ÄúI am alover, but adopting one is a challenge due to my work schedule and the presence of children at home.A week ago, I found Tyson at our gate, and he looked scared and hungry. He also had a collar around his neck, which means he was someone‚Äôs pet. It was drizzling too, so we took him in and fed him.‚Äù After some investigation, Nambiar, a resident of Wheeler Road, found that Tyson had been abandoned by his parents. ‚ÄúWe are looking for someone to adopt him and give him the kind of love he needs. Letting him go will be tough, but the purpose of fostering is to prevent animals from becoming strays and homeless.‚ÄùPamela Parashar, an animal caregiver, says the number of abandoned dogs have increased over the last few months. ‚ÄúMost people took in puppies during the lockdown. Now that offices have started functioning,have been abandoned,‚Äù says the Cooke Town resident.In 2013, Reena Chengappa picked up a weakfrom the road, as he was causing a traffic jam near Ulsoor. He had tick fever. He was unpredictable and not docile - a sign of past trauma. Chengappa and her husbandworked with a canine therapist and a vet. After many families adopted him and returned him, Chengappa kept him till he passed away. Saad Pasha, vice president of FluffyNut Foundation, says foster parents are a godsend to strays and abandoned animals. ‚ÄúAfter a point, shelter homes become full. Sometimes dogs also have a chance of getting infected here. So a foster home is safer and the need of the hour.‚ÄùGood on you,. Many karma credits coming your way.

Title: Notice slapped on organiser of Baramati camp in vaccine row
Content:
When BCG became Covishield

political ploy

inquiry

vaccination camp

tuberculosis

BCG vaccine

Vaishali Rahatkar

Baramati taluka

tehsil

A day after anwas initiated into ain Baramati‚Äôs Malegaon village for allegedly doling out avaccine under the name of one against COVID-19, the district health department has slapped a notice on the organiser of the event.Jaydeep Taware, former sarpanch of Malegaon, was the main organiser of the camp held on Sunday. Thereafter, some villagers had raised a complaint with the district administration, alleging that the organisers of the camp were advertising that they were distributing vaccine against COVID-19 at Rs 200 per person ‚Äî in reality, it was the Bacillus Calmette‚ÄìGu√©rin orfor TB.On September 9, Mirror had reported that an inquiry was being initiated into the complaint against the vaccination camp in the article, ‚ÄòTB vaccine allegedly passed off as Covishield at Baramati vaccination camp‚Äô. A local political leader and husband of the sarpanch had also confirmed that some villagers had contacted him, claiming that the vaccine being manufactured by Serum Institute of India (SII) was being administered at the camp.Aday after the inquiry, organiser Taware was served a notice on Wednesday by district medical officials. Dr, the medical officer, said, ‚ÄúWhen we received the plaint that such a programme was organised in Malegaon Budruk, we verified the information and found out that the camp was indeed held on the weekend, and witnessed a gathering of villagers.‚ÄùShe added, ‚ÄúAfter the confirmation, we issued a notice to the organiser seeking an explanation. Through this notice, we have also prohibited him from organising any such camps in the near future as the village is a containment zone.‚ÄùBaramati health officer Dr Manoj Khomane has already given a letter topolice station, seeking a police inquiry into the incident. When contacted on this topic, inspector in charge of the PS, Annasaheb Gholap, said, ‚ÄúThough there are prohibitory orders for public gatherings, healthrelated meetings and gatherings are exempted as they fall under essential services. Since it requires an expert opinion to decide whether a medical camp falls under the violation of government order or not, we have requested the health official to submit a report of inquiry to us. Based on that, further action will be taken in the matter.‚ÄùMeanwhile, Taware maintained that he did not have any ill intentions behind organising the camp. ‚ÄúThis was not the first vaccination camp in the. Before this, three or four more were held. The complaint against me has been made out of a political vendetta. My only intention was to help the villagers in boosting their immunity during the COVID-19 pandemic, due to which the BCG vaccine was given out. I never announced that it was the vaccine against COVID-19,‚Äù he refuted..

Title: Welcome to the 8-hour commute: Unlock IV without making adequate arrangements has turned citizens‚Äô commute into a nightmare
Content:
local trains

BMC gets ready to buy RT-PCR kits in case central supplies stop The BMC is preparing to buy RTPCR Covid-19 kits on its own in case the Centre stops supplying them, a senior civic official said on Wednesday. The Centre has indicated that states may soon have to shoulder the responsibility of procuring their own RT-PCR kits and other material. It is not clear whether that means the

Crime record not a hurdle for contesting elections to cooperative societies The state legislature has passed an amendment nullifying a provision that barred candidates with criminal background.

Sanjay Singh

Sanjay Singh (inset)

Rajesh Ganatra

Rajesh Ganatra (inset)

Nemaram Prajapati

Nemaram Prajapati (inset)

Nidhi Kamdar

Nidhi Kamdar (inset)

Angela Lainez

Angela Lainez (inset)

Savita Subramanian

Savita Subramanian (inset)

Amrita Kuvare

Amrita Kuvare (inset)

Since mid-July, Virar East resident Nemaram Prajapati has been spending nine hours a day travelling to and from his place of work. He leaves home before 5 am and walks to Virar West to wait in line for a bus to Nariman Point. From there he walks to the shop at Crawford Market where he works as a kitchen utensil salesman. After eight hours of work, he begins his return journey and gets back home past midnight, when his wife and four children are fast asleep. The silver lining - if you can call it one - is that Prajapati only has to go to work on alternate days. Nonetheless, the hellish nine-hour daily commute leaves him shattered.Withstill restricted to essential workers, eight and nine-hour commutes have become part of the new normal for thousands like Prajapati. Even those who live relatively close to their place of work are spending close to eight hours a day commuting. Among them is 54-year-old Dombivali resident Angela Lainez, who works as a cook at a church in Thane.Before the lockdown, it used to take her just an hour to get to work and another hour to return. Now, the absence of local trains and long queues for buses mean she spends seven hours a day on her commute. This means she has to wake up at 3 am every day to cook for her husband mother-in-law before leaving for work.Mirror spoke to seven such people on Wednesday. Read below about their harrowing stories - and incredible resilience.-------------------------------------------------------, 47KALYAN (W) |MAHALAXMI8 HOURS3 HOURSSanjay Singh‚Äôs family is worried about the toll that the long commute is taking on his health. The engineer, who works at a construction firm at Mahalaxmi, leaves home at 6 am and does not return before 11 pm. ‚ÄúI hardly get 4-5 hours of sleep a day,‚Äù he tells Mirror.Before the lockdown, Singh left at 8 am and returned home by 8.30 pm, he tells Mirror while queuing up at the ST bus depot at Kalyan (West). Now, for the past two months, Singh has suffered from back pain. ‚ÄúWhen I reach home I am not able to sit because of the pain.‚ÄùSingh‚Äôs commute to Byculla ‚Äì from where he walks to Mahalaxmi ‚Äì begins with a two-hour wait at the depot. That, however, is nothing compared to the situation in the evening, when the buses are full and he has to wait for 4-5 hours.Once home, Singh washes his clothes, takes a shower, finishes his dinner and hits the bed ‚Äì but not before setting the alarm for 4.30 am.Singh wishes he could spend more time with his family ‚Äì he and his wife have two sons, aged 20 and 23. ‚ÄúI hardly get to speak to them during the weekdays.‚Äù---------------------------------------------------, 46VASAI |NARIMAN POINT8 HOURS4 HOURSVasai resident Rajesh Ganatra works at a private firm at Nariman Point that supplies carpets and vinyl flooring to government organisations. He told Mirror that the lockdown has turned his commute into a nightmare. He wakes up at 4 am to catch the 6.30 am bus and spends eight to nine hours a day travelling to and from work.‚ÄúI have been doing this for the past one-and-a-half months. It takes me about three hours to reach Mantralaya as the Western Express Highway gets jammed by 8.30 am. The journey back home in the evening is even worse and usually takes five to six hours. When it‚Äôs just five hours, I feel lucky,‚Äù Ganatra said. On the ‚Äúbright‚Äù side, he has to travel to work only thrice a week. But he can be called in on other days, too. Before the lockdown it used to take him just two hours to reach work by train and another two hours to return home. ‚ÄúTravelling for eight to nine hours a day saps your energy and affects your productivity,‚Äù he said.--------------------------------------------------------, 46VIRAR (E) |CRAWFORD MARKET9 HOURS2 TO 3 HOURSSSince mid-July, Nemaram Prajapati has been spending nine hours a day travelling to and from his place of work. A kitchen utensil salesman, he returns home past midnight, when his wife and four children are already fast asleep. The only silver lining is that he only has to go to work on alternate days and sometimes gets a two-day break. Before the lockdown, he used to spend ‚Äúonly‚Äù two to three hours a day travelling.Prajapati said he leaves his home before 5 am and walks from Virar East to the MSRTC terminal in Virar West. ‚ÄúI wake up at 4 am and only have time for a cup of tea. I cannot expect my wife to cook that early, so I order lunch and dinner at work. This costs me Rs 4,500 a month,‚Äù he said. After leaving work at 7 pm, he walks to CSMT, from where he takes a bus to Sion or Dadar. From there he boards another bus, which takes him to Kashimira. From there he gets in an auto with two other passengers and pays Rs 100 for the journey to Virar. He returns home around 12.30 am.---------------------------------------------------------, 21VASAI |CHURCHGATE8 HOURS2 TO 3 HOURSNidhi Kamdar, 21, an accountant with a private firm at Churchgate, wakes up at 5 am every day and takes the 7 am ST bus from Vasai. She reaches her office at 9.30 am. To allow her a few extra minutes of rest, her father Hiren Kamdar stands in the bus queue from 5.20 am and leaves when she gets there around 6.30 am. Prior to the lockdown, she would take the 8.30 am Churchgate local and reach her office by 10 am. Her evening commute is far worse and usually takes five hours. She gets back home around 11 pm, leaving her with just an hour to unwind and eat dinner before it‚Äôs time for bed. Before the lockdown, she would be back home by 9.30 pm.‚ÄúI work for eight hours and commute for eight hours. I don‚Äôt have time for my family or for myself. All my time at home is spent sleeping. I hope the trains restart soon so we don‚Äôt have to struggle this much,‚Äù she said.-----------------------------------------------------, 54DOMBIVALI |THANE6 TO 7 HOURS1 TO 1.5 HOURSAt 4.30 am on Wednesday, Angela Lainez was at the front of a long queue of people waiting outside Dombivali station. For the past couple of months, Lainez, who works as a cook at St John the Baptist Church in Thane, has spent nearly four hours a day on buses to and from work, and another three hours standing in queues. When local trains were running it would take her just half an hour to get to work and around the same time to reach home. Her husband works at a remote factory and her son works from home. The household also includes her 86-year-old mother-in-law. Lainez wakes up at 3 am to cook for them. Dombivali residents who want to return home by bus have to go to the MSRTC bus stand at Khopat, where the buses get more crowded as the day progresses. Luckily for Lainez, the priest at the church told her she could leave two hours early every day, at 3 pm. ‚ÄúIf I rush out and get a rickshaw to Khopat, I can reach home by 5:30 pm. But if I miss that bus I don‚Äôt reach home before 7 pm,‚Äù she said.---------------------------------------------------------, 47BADLAPUR |ANDHERI EAST8 HOURS4 HOURSBadlapur resident Savita Subramanian works with a chemicals supplier at Andheri East. Before the lockdown, she used to spend four hours a day commuting. But since June, her travel time has doubled. Pre-lockdown, she used to leave home at 7 am and reach her office at 8.15 am. She would take a local train to Ghatkopar, then the Metro to Marol. She would work until 5 pm and return home by 7 pm. But now, she has to leave home at 5.30 am and board a bus at 6.15 am to arrive at her office at the same time.Though she now gets to leave work an hour earlier, at 4 pm, her return journey is hellish. ‚ÄúI leave the office at 4 pm and take an auto to Ghatkopar. From there I take a BEST bus to Khopat, and from there I take an ST bus to Badlapur. I then have to take an auto home,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI have started suffering from back problems because of this commute,‚Äù she added.------------------------------------------------------, 29KALYAN |VIKHROLI7 TO 8 HOURS3 HOURSAmrita Kuvare hardly gets time for her 12-year-old son. She leaves at 6 am and is seldom home before 10 pm. Kuvare works for a Vikhroli-based company. In the morning she usually gets a direct bus from Kalyan (after waiting for around two hours). While returning she changes bus at Mulund Check Naka, then takes an auto till Kopari. From Kopari she gets another bus for Kalyan. Before Kuvare leaves home, she prepares food for her son. In the evening she has to make dinner for the whole family. ‚ÄúEvery day as I prepare to leave for office my son asks, ‚ÄòMother, when will you return?‚Äô I reply, ‚ÄòDon‚Äôt worry son,‚Äô and quickly leave. I am not able to face him,‚Äù she says. Kuvare‚Äôs husband works at BKC. He leaves home at 8 am and returns after 11 pm.

Title: Rakul Preet Singh gets goofy again
Content: One of the most social media savvy actresses, Rakul Preet Singh recently put up a post with the above picture that had her putting up one of her favourite expressions. She wrote: "The goofy expression caught amidst all the posing #realvsreel." Being goofy has always been her favourite expression, even when it comes to her favourite emoji. This was evident on the day everyone celebrated World Emoji Day on July 17. The actress chose to enact the 'goofy' expression - the emoji with the tongue out. "World emoji day.. my goofy expression forever .. I am sure my friends agree," she wrote in the caption of this picture that she posted.Rakul is known to put up positive posts as well as fitness videos. However, she has been missing her workouts of late, especially yoga. Posting a picture of her yoga workout, she wrote: "Body isn‚Äôt stiff ! Mind is @anshukayoga when when when will we hop back on that hammock misssss u." Her trainer in turn responded: "@rakulpreet miss you more!!! Can‚Äôt wait to have our inverted hammock conversations."She also took part in a challenge of a different kind - this one is called 'You Are What You Eat', where she was nominated by South actress Samantha Akkineni : Sharing the video, she wrote:"Thankuuuu @samantharuthprabhuoffl for nominating me üòò‚ù§Ô∏è.. YOU ARE WHAT YOU EAT . Its such a lovely experience to watch these seeds pop out and then grow into food for our nourishment. It‚Äôs said when you grow your food it adapts according to your individual body needs. Let‚Äôs connect with nature, with ourselves . Let‚Äôs grow together #growwithme @urbankisaan." On the workfront, Rakul is set to share the screen space with the likes of John Abraham and Jacqueline Fernandez in 'Attack'. She will also be seen in Kamal Haasan's 'Indian 2'.

Title: India China LAC stand-off: India will retaliate in case China breaches red lines, says top official
Content: NEW DELHI: Warning China that there will be requisite retaliation if any red-lines are now breached in eastern Ladakh, a top government official on Wednesday said India has further reinforced its forward positions to counter fresh Chinese military build-ups and threatening moves in the high-altitude region.The warning comes after bullets were fired for the first time in 45 years near the Mukhpari Top in the Chushul sector on Monday, and ahead of an expected meeting between foreign minister S Jaishankar and his Chinese counterpart Wang Yi in Moscow on Thursday.The People‚Äôs Liberation Army (PLA) has taken to parading tanks and troops in the south bank of Pangong Tso-Chushul area on a daily basis in a bid to intimidate Indian troops after they occupied multiple tactical heights there in a proactive military manoeuvre on August 29-30.‚ÄúThe dispute is being directed from the very top of the political-military hierarchy in China, not by the exuberance of local PLA commanders. It can take any trajectory. But if China wants to start a war, it will also have to pay a heavy price,‚Äù the official said, pointing out that the events at the LAC were not just an action-reaction sequence.The PLA might even try to grab heights elsewhere in a tit-for-tat move but the Indian commanders on the ground have been given ‚Äúfull freedom‚Äù to respond as they deem appropriate. ‚ÄúOur soldiers on the heights are well-armed and fully-prepared. We have even driven tanks up the ridgeline near Rechin La (Reqin mountain pass),‚Äù said the official.The message has been strongly conveyed to the PLA to not try to breach Indian perimeter defences, which includes barbed wire, established on the heights. ‚ÄúThey constitute a red-line. In fact, nowhere are we under-prepared now," he added.The Indian security establishment‚Äôs assessment is that while China may have positioned around 50,000 soldiers along the frontier in eastern Ladakh as well as around 150 fighters, bombers and other aircraft at airbases in Xinjiang and Tibet, the deployments have not yet reached the threshold of a full-blown conflict.The official said ‚ÄúPLA troop deployments along the Line of Actual Control (LAC) in eastern Ladakh are not tactically geared for war as of now. But yes, the pinpricks will continue‚Äù.India has sought another meeting of the rival corps commanders, who have met five times earlier, to defuse the tensions in the Pangong Tso-Chushul area. But the Indian Army, which has matched the Chinese force-levels, are now also prepared for all contingencies after initially being surprised by the PLA move to occupy the 8-km stretch from ‚ÄòFinger-4 to 8‚Äô (mountainous spurs) on the north bank of Pangong Tso in early-May.The PLA was paid back in its own coin when Indian soldiers seized heights on the ridge line stretching from the southern bank of Pangong Tso at Thakung to Gurung Hill, Spanggur Gap, Magar Hill, Mukhpari, Rezang La and Reqin La on August 29-30.As earlier reported by TOI, Indian soldiers also simultaneously occupied heights overlooking the PLA deployments on the ridgeline over `Finger-4‚Äô on the north bank of Pangong Tso. ‚ÄúWe have applied counter-pressure points now,‚Äù he said.In the `Finger-4‚Äô area, PLA troops will now have to deploy to an altitude of over 17,000-feet if they want to gain a tactical advantage over the Indian soldiers there. ‚ÄúThe distance between the rival troops on the heights is just 100-200 meters, while it is around 2-km at the level of the lake,‚Äù said the official.On the southern bank of Pangong Tso, the PLA holds the Helmet Top, Yellow Bump and Black Top features along the LAC. The PLA, in fact, has installed cameras on the heights to monitor the activities of the Indian soldiers in the region. ‚ÄúBut we are also watching them closely. From the heights we occupy, the PLA‚Äôs Moldo garrison is clearly visible,‚Äù said another officer.

Title: BMC never sent any notice to me until yesterday: Kangana Ranaut terms document dated 2018 as 'fake'
Content:
Paid sources of Maha government are spreading fake info,BMC never sent any notice to me until yesterday,in fact I g‚Ä¶ https://t.co/oQ05dFKefH ‚Äî Kangana Ranaut (@KanganaTeam) 1599662905000

Terming a document stating that BMC had sent a notice regarding unauthorised construction in her Mumbai in 2018, as "fake," actor Kangana Ranaut on Wednesday said that BMC had never "sent any notice" to her until Tuesday.The 'Queen' actor took to Twitter to share a copy of the said document and accused the Maharashtra government of "spreading fake" information."Paid sources of Maha government are spreading fake info, BMC never sent any notice to me until yesterday," she tweeted."In fact I got all the documents cleared myself from BMC for renovations. [?]@mybmc [?] at least have the courage to stand by your audacity. why lie now?," she added.The document dated October 20, 2018, had been doing rounds on Twitter since Wednesday morning.In a parallel development, the Bombay High Court had earlier in the day stayed the demolition drive being undertaken by the Brihanmumbai Municipal Corporation (BMC) at Kangana's property.A bench of the High Court also asked the BMC to file a reply to her petition in the matter.Ranaut, through her lawyer Rizwan Siddiqui , had moved the High Court against the demolition of what the BMC termed as "illegal alterations" at her office.Earlier today, Ranaut took to Twitter to state "my Mumbai is POK now" and posted photographs of city municipal corporation officials demolishing parts of her property in the city.

Title: Shawn Mendes to perform at 2020 Toronto Film Festival Tribute Awards
Content: Musician Shawn Mendes is all set to grace the stage of the 2020 Toronto Film Festival Tribute Awards with a special performance.According to a report, the organisation on Wednesday said that he will be endowing the new Shawn Mendes Foundation changemaker Award at the show along with his performance.The award prize of a whopping USD 10,000 dollars will be given to a film that revolves around driving a social change.The musician's foundation will also be making an annual contribution to support the next wave of TIFF and to help it in delivering key initiatives to elevate young voices."Shawn shares TIFF's commitment to elevating and empowering young changemakers to transforming the world through advocacy, and we're absolutely thrilled to have him join us to perform at this year's TIFF Tribute Awards as we honour the film industry's contributors," Joana Vincente , executive director and co-head of TIFF, was quoted saying.The 45th edition of the Toronto International Film Festival will run from September 10 to September 19.

Title: 76% of patents filed in India in last 13 years were by foreign companies
Content:
Qualcomm, Huawei Top Foreign Cos

BENGALURU: Nearly eight out of every ten patent applications filed in India in more than a decade have been by foreigners residing abroad. A majority are by foreign firms, even as the number of Indian applications is slowly increasing.More than 5.1 lakh patent applications were filed in the country between 2005-06 and 2017-18 according to the data compiled by the Department of Science and Technology (DST) as part of the latest Science & Technology Indicators (STI 2019-20) released last month.And, an analysis of the data shows that more than 76% of these applications were filed by "foreigners resident abroad", as the government classifies them and the rest were by "Indians."This is a trend experts say India must arrest. ‚ÄúWe have to be more innovative,‚Äù Biocon Ltd executive chairperson Kiran Mazumdar Shaw said.A senior defence scientist told TOI that India does not lack talent and that even investments are improving, especially in the private sector. He said India lacked the right ecosystem. The TOI had reported last month about how R&D investments by the private sector has been growing at twice the rate of public/government investment.In March 2016, noted scientist Prof CNR Rao, who has consistently batted for increased funding for science and had remarked: ‚ÄúResearchers are relaxing with too much furniture!‚ÄùAmong the patents filed by foreigners, most are individuals or companies from the US, Japan and Germany, accounting for more than 45% of the patents in the said period, while the UK, France, Switzerland , Russia, Netherlands and Italy also had hundreds of applications filed.With nearly 1.4 lakh applications, patents filed by those from the US alone accounted for more than 27% of total applications filed in the said period.Former Isro chairman K Kasturirangan, who also headed India‚Äôs committee on new education policy told TOI: ‚Äú...We need to really improve research content at major institutions and particularly at the 900-odd universities in the country. We have to make sure that pure research becomes part of applied research, which goes into translational and industrial research. Unless this four-pronged attack is made on research to create more innovation and ideas, the question of patent doesn‚Äôt arise.‚ÄùIn fact, the proposal for the National Research Foundation (NRF) in the education policy, he said, is the reflection of concerns about some of these outcomes of research. ‚ÄúI hope that we improve research as fast as we can and create an environment that leads to an ecosystem of more innovation and products that are patentable,‚Äù he added.The STI-2019-20 also provides data on top foreign companies filing patents in the five years between 2013-14 and 2017-18. Analysis shows that most of the top 19 companies were tech and telecom firms, including Chinese MNC Huawei Technologies.Qualcomm Incorporated‚Äîan American semiconductor and telecommunications equipment firm ‚Äî tops the table with 6,960 applications, followed by Dutch multinational firm Koninklijke Philips, which had 3,670 applications.The TOI had reported in July 2018 on how Qualcomm alone had filed more than twice the number of patents than the collective number of applications from 50 labs under the DRDO, 38 labs under CSIR, 23 IITs, 31 NITs, more than 40 labs in the IISc and six major research facilities under Isro, in 2016-17.Aside from these two firms, Huawei had filed 1,393 patents in the said period, while other big firms like Google, Microsoft Technology Licencing, Siemens , Robert Bosch and others also filed hundreds of applications.

Title: Kangana Ranaut row: HC hammers BMC for its haste in razing parts of Kangana Ranaut's bungalow
Content:
Read Also

MUMBAI: Observing that the conduct of the BMC , which carried out demolition of allegedly unauthorised constructions at actor Kangana Ranaut ‚Äôs bungalow in Pali Hill, Bandra, on Wednesday, was ‚Äúhighly deplorable‚Äù, the Bombay high court in a scathing order directed the municipal body to immediately stop the demolition.The HC bench of Justices S JKathawalla and Riyaz Chagla said ‚Äúthough the manner in which BMC proceeded to commence the demolition prima facie...smacks of mala fide...it was giving an opportunity to corporation to explain its conduct on affidavit by Thursday.‚ÄùThe order came at an urgent hearing within hours of a civic squad launching the demolition. The BMC, controlled by Shiv Sena which is part of the ruling Maha Vikas Aghadi alliance in the state, had despatched a squad with heavy machinery to her place in the morning and flattened portions of the rowhouse.Kangana, who was vacationing in her hometown in Himachal Pradesh , landed in the city a few hours after the BMC‚Äôs action began. Before she reached Mumbai, Kangana, through her lawyer Rizwan Siddiquee , had approached HC to prevent the ‚Äúillegal, arbitrary and mala fide‚Äù demolition, which she claimed was ‚Äúa fallout over the difference of opinion with certain influential people operating in the civic administration and the Maharashtra government‚Äù.She sought directions to quash the BMC‚Äôs stop-work notice issued on Tuesday. The HC bench said, ‚ÄúIt is clear that the unauthorised works have not come up overnight. However, all of a sudden, the corporation appears to have woken up from its slumber, issued notice to the petitioner... when she is out of the state, directing her to respond within 24 hours, and not granting her any further time despite written request, and proceeding to demolish‚Ä¶on completion of 24 hours.‚ÄùThe HC added, ‚Äú...If the BMC would act with similar swiftness on the numerous unauthorised constructions in this city, it (the city) would be a completely different place to live in.‚Äù The HC found fault with the BMC‚Äôs conduct, ‚Äúmore so‚Äù since it had filed a caveat expecting her petition.The bench informed senior counsel Anil Sakhare that ‚Äúsuch conduct...is totally unacceptable‚Äù. When the matter was called out at 12.30pm, initially no lawyer appeared for BMC, and Siddiquee said by then, 40% of the premises was razed.

Title: Pimpri grade separator to stay shut for Metro work
Content:
Pune: The grade separator at Pimpri, on the old Pune-Mumbai highway, will stay shut to vehicular traffic for the next few days to facilitate Metro work.

Traffic will be diverted via service roads on both sides of the road. MahaMetro is constructing pillars for the Metro‚Äôs viaduct at the site.

Traffic on Pune-Mumbai lane has been diverted for last few days and vehicles using Mumbai-Pune lane have to travel through the service road via diverted route. Diversions will remain in place mainly during night. Traffic will be diverted during daytime as per requirement.

The ongoing Metro work in Pimpri stretch is part of the Metro‚Äôs Pimpri-Civil Court-Swargate corridor. Work related to construction of pillars, launching of segments, construction of station is currently under way. The BRTS route has also been closed to traffic. MahaMetro officials and traffic police visited the stretch to chalk out traffic diversion plan. A detailed plan of work has been submitted by MahaMetro to the police. Steps are being taken to complete the work at the earliest.

Title: Govt divests 13% in Bharat Dynamics
Content:
TNN

Mumbai: The government mobilised Rs 776 crore by divesting nearly 13% in Bharat Dynamics ( BDL ) through an offer-for-sale ( OFS ) that closed on Wednesday. The government, which initially offered a little over 1.8 crore shares or 10% in the company at a floor price of Rs 330 per share, enhanced the offer size by another 5% to a combined offering of about 2.7 crore shares.

According to the OFS data on the BSE website, a little over 2.3 crore shares were subscribed. A tweet by the secretary, Dipam, the government department responsible for its divestment process, also confirmed the fund mobilisation. The Dipam secretary said the divestment was mainly aimed at meeting the Sebi ‚Äôs minimum public shareholding ( MPS ) norm.

After the OFS, the public shareholding in BDL will fall from the current level of 87.75% to just a bit less than the 75% limit to meet Sebi norms. Since the OFS was launched, BDL stock on BSE slid to close the day‚Äôs session at Rs 314, down 5%.

Title: J P Nadda to visit Bihar on Friday
Content:
BJP national president J P Nadda

PATNA: BJP national president J P Nadda‚Äôs two-day poll-related visit to the state will begin on Friday. He will interact with party‚Äôs top brass, besides traditional professional caste groups from the countryside and women kisans (farmers), including Padma Shri award winner Rajkumari Devi, who is popular as Kisan Chachi.

After reaching Patna on Friday evening, Nadda will hold organizational meetings, BJP state general secretary Dewesh Kumar said. He will also interact with the 70-member steering committee headed by Union minister Nityanand Rai, and might also meet the core committee members. Nadda is supposed to goad the steering committee members to reach out to people in a novel way.

Nadda will fly to Darbhanga on Saturday to have sessions with fishermen‚Äôs community and the makhana growers. From Darbhanga, he will visit Muzaffarpur to meet the women ‚Äòkisans‚Äô from Sitamarhi and Samastipur besides Muzaffarpur at Paru.

He will return to Delhi on Saturday.

Title: Youth held on charge of raping minor
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: The Yerawada police on Tuesday arrested a 20-year-old youth for allegedly raping a 14-year-old girl and making her pregnant.

The girl‚Äôs mother registered an FIR against the youth, accusing him of repeatedly raping her daughter since January 10.

Police said the girl is a student of standard VII, while the boy is a college dropout.

Her mother stated in the complaint that the youth had been pursuing her daughter for a relationship, despite her repeated refusal.

He then started harassing and threatening her, saying that he would defame her. The youth also threatened to end his life for refusing his overtures, the mother stated. The youth forced the girl into a physical relationship with him, the complaint stated.

Sub-inspector, Yerawada police, Shubangi Magdum, said, ‚ÄúThe girl initially feared reporting the boy‚Äôs act to her parents, but after realising that she was pregnant, she eventually confided in her mother and narrated the details.‚Äù

Magdum said, ‚ÄúWe have arrested the youth after the survivor‚Äôs mother registered a complaint under the relevant sections of the Indian Penal Code and Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act. We have admitted the girl in a government hospital for medical examination. The suspect has been remanded in police custody till Friday,‚Äù she added.

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: Bihar deputy CM Sushil Kumar Modi asks bankers to give more loans
Content:
Deputy CM Sushil Kumar Modi

PATNA: Deputy CM Sushil Kumar Modi on Wednesday asked the bankers to increase loaning activities under the state‚Äôs annual credit plan (ACP) in the 10 districts where loan disbursement has been less than 10% of the target. The 10 districts include Banka (6.29%), Arwal (6.29%), Madhubani (7.28%) and Siwan (8.01%). Modi, who is also the state finance minister, asked the bankers to review the situation within the next 15 days.

Addressing the 73rd state level bankers‚Äô committee meeting, he said the state government has provided to pay 15-35% of the capital and interest as subsidy in the handicraft sector and in the commercial farming sector like makhana, fruits and vegetables, honey, maize and seeds that require processing, but the bankers have shown reluctance to provide loans to the farmers.

He also noted the poor loaning activities for the footpath vendors, who have to be given Rs10,000 each as loan under Atmanirbhar Bharat programme of the Centre. Of the 14,917 applications submitted, only 3,974 were accepted and the bankers processed only 45 of them. The urban development department has asked the bankers to provide loans to 1 lakh footpath vendors.

Similarly, Modi said 2.5 crore farmers with kisan credit cards (KCCs) had to be given Rs2 lakh loan each, but only 69,689 had been given the facility. In the micro small and medium enterprises (MSME) sector, Rs2,051 crore had been disbursed among 1.17 lakh applicants.

Finance department principal secretary S Siddharth also addressed the bankers.

Title: Bihar: Congress talks about Madhubani issues
Content:
Representative image

PATNA: Congress leaders raised local issues while attacking the NDA government at the virtual rally for Madhubani and Supaul districts on Wednesday.

Local Congress leaders talked about migrant labourers, closed sugar mills, the ongoing row over the GI tag for makhana and teaching of Maithili in schools. Congress MLC Prem Chandra Mishra said changing the GI tag of Mithila Makhana to that of Bihar was a controversy and a way to destroy the identity of the region. ‚ÄúWe will never let this happen. Can Hajipur bananas be called that of Bihar, or khaja of silao and Bhagalpuri silk for instance are named after the region. Also, the present government had intentionally removed Maithili teaching from schools as they did not want students to study this language. They are afraid that the students from this region will become IAS and IPS officers,‚Äù said Mishra.

Former MP Shakeel Ahmad, MLA from Benipatti in Madhubani, Bhawana Jha, former Haryana minister Captain Ajay Yadav and Alka Lamba talked about the plights of migrant labourers.

Senior Congress leader Pramod Tiwari hit out at CM Nitish Kumar.

Title: Happiest minds ipo: Startup@77: Ashok Soota scores in 2nd innings
Content: BENGALURU/MUMBAI: It‚Äôs rare for entrepreneurs to succeed a second time. To do that in their 70s ‚Äî almost never. Ashok Soota , 77, is one of those exceptional ones. The Rs 700-crore initial public offer (IPO) of his IT services company Happiest Minds , which concluded on Wednesday, has been oversubscribed 150 times.About 13 years ago, he took his previous company, Mindtree , to an IPO, and that issue was oversubscribed 103 times.‚ÄúPeople thought we were crazy to file for an IPO in the middle of a lockdown ,‚Äù Soota told TOI last week. But he said he was confident, given the nature of his business. He said almost 76% of his revenue is not affected by the pandemic and lockdown.More than half of that revenue comes from edutech and hi-tech sectors. He said the company‚Äôs focus on digital services also puts it on a very different footing from traditional IT companies. This is what enables, he said, Happiest Minds to grow at nearly 21% (last three years‚Äô compounded annual growth rate, or CAGR), when the IT industry has slowed down to 8-10%.The Happiest Minds IPO raised Rs 316 crore from anchor investors last week, before the issue opened. The IPO closed with a book size of nearly Rs 58,300 crore. The institutional part has been subscribed over 77 times, the non-institutional part ‚Äî also called the HNI or the high net worth investors‚Äô portion ‚Äî 352 times, and the retail portion 71 times. This is the second IPO since the lockdown started in March. The first, of Rossari Biotech in July, was oversubscribed 79 times.Soota did engineering from IIT-Roorkee, and was in Shriram Refrigeration Industries when Azim Premji, in 1985, hired him to build Wipro‚Äôs then nascent IT business. Over the next 14 years, Soota became almost the face of Wipro, given Premji‚Äôs proclivity to stay in the background, and rose to be vice-chairman of the company.In 1999, Soota led a group of 10 senior executives, from Wipro and other companies, to found Mindtree. The going was good for the next decade, and the successful IPO in 2007 only increased the optimism.But then there emerged differences between the founders, and it looked like it was Soota on one side and all the rest on the other. It‚Äôs still not very clear what the differences were. Some attribute it to Soota‚Äôs push for an entry into the mobile handset business, which ended up losing a lot of money. Some say there were differences around the allocation of responsibilities among the founders.Eventually, Soota quit Mindtree. He sold off all his shares in the company, and in 2011, at the age of 68, in a remarkable display of grit and perseverance, he founded Happiest Minds.Soota told TOI in an earlier interview that he named the company Happiest Minds to suggest that they are in the business of making customers happy through happy employees. But since Happiest Minds did not quite indicate what the company did, Soota added the tagline ‚Äî The Mindful IT Company , which conveyed that it was an IT company that would be mindful in its approach to its people, customers and community.The company‚Äôs biggest differentiator, Soota said, was its focus on digital ‚Äî while most of the big IT services companies today categorise about 30% to 50% of their business as digital, for Happiest Minds, it‚Äôs 100%. Soota believes there are only four firms in the world that can be called 100% digital ‚Äî Happiest Minds, Epam Systems, Endava and Globant.Soota said last week that he had always preferred to run public companies. He said there‚Äôs pressure to improve corporate governance when a company goes public. Depending too much on private capital, he said, doesn‚Äôt help. He points to the experience of heavily funded companies like Uber and Lyft. ‚ÄúThey have been trading below their IPO price,‚Äù he said.

Title: YC Continuity leads $30m Groww round
Content:
BENGALURU: Famed Silicon Valley accelerator Y Combinator ‚Äôs $700-million growth fund ‚Äî YC Continuity ‚Äî is leading a funding round in an Indian startup for the first time. YC Continuity, which invests in growth-stage startups, has led a $30-million round in online investment platform Groww .

Started in 2017, the Bengaluru-based firm offers mutual funds-to-stock investments through its platform, while it expands into other financial services products on the back of new funding. Groww‚Äôs existing investors Sequoia India , Ribbit Capital and Propel Ventures have also participated in this round.

YC Continuity partner Anu Hariharan will join the board of the company as part of the investment. Previously, YC Continuity had participated in a funding round for payments startup Razorpay in 2018. While the fund largely invests in Y Combinator or YC alumni firms, it has backed non-YC firms like UK‚Äôs Monzo. In the US, it has also backed some of the most valued companies like Stripe, DoorDash and Coinbase.

Groww co-founder and CEO Lalit Keshre said the company will invest the new capital in its technology infrastructure, expand its product suite and hire across product and growth divisions in the firm. ‚ÄúWe have seen mutual fund inflows doubling to around Rs 500 crore through our platform in August compared to January. We have just started enabling investing in US stocks like Amazon, Google, Apple, and would also introduce investment in derivatives,‚Äù he added.

Groww also sells gold digitally and about 60% of its users are from tier-2 and -3 cities. The online financial services space has been seeing increased action from startups like Zerodha, Paytm, PhonePe and ETMoney, which is part of the group which publishes TOI.

Title: Senior citizen from Pune gives up gold chain for mud
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: Two women, who had worn masks, stole a gold chain worth Rs45,000 from a 65-year-old woman by diverting her attention on the pretext of offering her gold beads packed in a small cloth pouch.

Shantabai Kamble from Solapur Bazaar realized she was tricked after she found mud in the cloth pouch, police said. The incident occurred between Mahatma Gandhi bus terminus and Hazrat Babajan Dargah chowk in Camp between 11.45am and 1.30pm on Tuesday.

Sub-inspector Akshay Sonawane from Cantonment police station said, ‚ÄúKamble reached the bus terminus from Golibar Maidan in an autorickshaw. The two women at the terminus requested her to take them to a jewellery store to sell nine gold beads.‚Äù

Sonawane said, ‚ÄúThe trio went to a jewellery store. The suspects showed the beads to the jeweller but he valued them at Rs2,000. They decided not to sell the beads. The women then lured her to keep the beads in exchange for her gold chain. Kamble offered her chain to the suspects but they diverted her attention and handed her a green pouch with beads and fled. On reaching home, Kamble opened the pouch filled with mud.‚Äù

Title: Inclusion of startups in priority sector no guarantee for funding
Content:
(Representative image)

CHENNAI: Stung by its inability to lend to startups due to legacy view on lending which asks for personal guarantee or collaterals, state run banks are chalking up products and processes, to fulfill a new regulator diktat ‚Äî including disbursals to startups.

For instance, Indian Bank is working on a product which would provide loans upto Rs 50 crore in installments. While this is welcome, the catch comes with the condition that loans can be availed against collateral only ‚Äî an uncomfortable area for startupreneurs.

Cross section of people in the startup ecosystem believe that RBI‚Äôs nudge will not make it easier for all startups to obtain bank credit but will lead to favourable terms for profit-making late stage ventures who were already making the cut for bank finance. Startups mentor and evangelist Vijay Anand said the typical requirements such as three years of financials, business projections, and some collateral security do not fit startups.

‚ÄúWe would need a massive overhaul of current lending systems to start lending to startups,‚Äù he said. Though, the apex bank‚Äôs move to bring in startup funding into the banking system is a good move, extending term loans to a startup does not fit into a risk profile meant for banks, analysts said. Vinod Murali, managing partner of venture debt firm Alteria Capital, said, ‚ÄúMost players in the startup ecosystem, who were earlier not eligible for bank loans, will still not be eligible. However, it will result in better commercial terms and pricing for companies that have always been eligible for bank financing.‚Äù

‚ÄúThere will also be more collaboration between banks and venture debt firms as there will be more interest from banks' side to participate in special debt vehicles,‚Äù Murali added. According to research firm Venture Intelligence , in the absence of adequate bank financing for startups, the total amount of venture debt deals in the ecosystem have gone up almost four times from 2016 to 2019 from $63 million to $215 million. Companies like ZoomCar, Dunzo, BigBasket and others are a few top players in the startup space that have raised venture debt.

Neel Juriasingani, co-founder and CEO, Datacultr said startups are more comfortable looking toward equity financing as the interest cost is a burden on ventures that are still figuring out profitability. We have to also go through tedious procedures just to open a bank account, and hence the lending process needs to be simplified for the move to have impact, he said.

‚ÄúIt is also a matter of perception; the investment from a PE or VC firm may involve equity dilution but brings in validation of the business idea,‚Äù he added. On the other hand, banks who felt directionless in developing loans for startups so far, laud RBI‚Äôs move to allow lending under the priority sector category. ‚ÄúSince, the upper limit is set at Rs 50 crore which will be disbursed in smaller parts, and gives us enough time to evaluate their business performance. Initial fund requirement for startups could be as low as Rs 10 lakh,‚Äù said Indian Bank‚Äôs general manager for MSME, Sudhakara Rao KS.

‚ÄúIt is impossible to provide loans, even under priority sector lending, without any minimal guarantee or collateral. Especially, with startups who have college graduates as promoters, who are new to business and new to credit. This poses a higher risk factor on lending,‚Äù Rao added.
